Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28 - Mod.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28 - Modification of Child Custody Orders
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28 - Mod.proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of an existing custody order based on substantial changes in circumstances and a best-interests analysis, seeking a change in primary physical custody. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas involves an initial divorce judgment awarding physical custody to the mother and permission to remove the children to Greece; it does not address standards for later modification of custody orders due to changed circumstances, nor does it involve transferring primary physical custody from one parent to another. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification request described in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child. There was extensive evidence concerning the children’s relations with their parents. The judge addressed the needs of the children and considered the physical care that each parent gave to each child. The fact that the evidence might have warranted a different decision on physical custody does not make the judge’s determination invalid.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The proposition is about modifying an existing custody order based on substantial changes in circumstances to award primary physical custody to one parent. Custody of Vaughn concerns an initial contested custody determination and the need for explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence on the child; it does not address the legal standard for post‑judgment modification based on changed circumstances or endorse a request to transfer primary custody on that basis. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Robbins v. Robbins, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 58.raw_text: Robbins v. Robbins, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 586 (1996)
Robbins v. Robbins, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 58.proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Robbins v. Robbins, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 58.case_name: Fox v. F & J Gattozzi Corp.
Robbins v. Robbins, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 58.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts contract/tort/business dispute about retirement benefits, negligent misrepresentation, unjust enrichment, and Statute of Frauds issues. It does not address family law, child custody, “best interests of the children,” or standards for modifying custody orders. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for modifying a custody order to grant primary physical custody based on substantial changes in circumstances.
Robbins v. Robbins, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 58.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs, Robert L. Fox and William S. Antonucci, brought a complaint in the Superior Court against the defendant, F & J Gattozzi Corporation (F & J), alleging a breach of an oral contract, negligent misrepresentation, and unjust enrichment. The action arose out of a dispute as to whether the plaintiffs were entitled to retirement benefits under the terms of an alleged oral contract.

Bodie v. Bodie, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (.raw_text: Bodie v. Bodie, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (1989)
Bodie v. Bodie, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (.proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Bodie v. Bodie, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of a child custody order based on substantial changes in circumstances and the best interests of the children. Bodie v. Bodie (despite the caption given) is actually a tort case about liability of parents for the intentional shooting committed by their adult son and about whether the son’s conduct was negligent or intentional. The opinion does not address child custody, domestic relations, or standards for modifying custody orders, so it cannot support the cited custody proposition.
Bodie v. Bodie, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs, Frederick McDonald and his son, Michael, appeal from a Superior Court judge’s entry of summary judgment in favor of the defendants, Stanley Lavery, Ann Lavery and their son, Peter. We affirm. It is not disputed that Frederick was seriously wounded on October 28, 1985, as a result of gunshots fired by Peter."

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7 10 - Be.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 10 - Best Interests of the Child
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7 10 - Be.proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2009).proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2009).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of an existing custody order to change primary physical custody between parents based on a substantial change in circumstances and the children’s best interests. Blixt v. Blixt addresses the constitutionality and construction of Massachusetts’ grandparent visitation statute, standards of harm, parental due process rights, and equal protection in the context of third‑party (grandparent) visitation, not parent-versus-parent custody modification. It neither sets out the legal standard for modifying custody orders nor discusses reallocating primary physical custody between parents, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “The statute adopts the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the test for determining visitation. This standard has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation and other issues relating to child welfare. The statute, however, uses the standard in a new context… We conclude, in rejection of the facial due process challenge made by the mother, that the statute satisfies strict scrutiny because our construction narrowly tailors it to further the compelling State interest in protecting the welfare of a child who has experienced a disruption in the family unit from harm.”

Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292 (1991).proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292 (1991).support_reasoning: The case deals with equitable division of marital property and the use of property interests as security for child support obligations, not with modification of child custody orders based on changed circumstances. While it discusses the Probate and Family Court’s authority regarding support and property, it does not address standards or procedures for modifying custody or determining primary physical custody in the best interests of children. Thus it does not provide authority for the requested modification of custody in the proposition.
Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28 (1988 ed.), provides in relevant part that ‘[u]pon a judgment for divorce, the court may make such judgment as it considers expedient relative to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children of the parties . . . .’ Building on § 28, G. L. c. 208, § 36, provides, in pertinent part: ‘When . . . support is adjudged for the . . . children, the court may require sufficient security for its payment according to the judgment.’… [§§ 28 and 36] together confer on probate judges broad discretion to fashion judgments…that will best protect the interests and welfare of the parties’ minor children.”

Grubert v. Grubert, 369 Mass. 304 (1975).proposition: 9. In light of the substantial changes in circumstances observed, the Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody of Liam and Ava to the Plaintiff, Emily Robinson, in the best interests of the children.
Grubert v. Grubert, 369 Mass. 304 (1975).support_reasoning: The excerpt from Grubert v. Grubert concerns the Supreme Judicial Court’s authority to review the constitutionality of statutes and the relationship between legislative judgment and judicial review. It does not address family law, child custody, modification of custody orders, or the best interests of the child standard. Therefore, it provides no support for a proposition seeking modification of a custody order based on changed circumstances and best interests of the children.
Grubert v. Grubert, 369 Mass. 304 (1975).relevant_excerpt: “Of course the General Court has the power and the duty to exercise ‘legislative judgment and policy.’ Such exercise of judgment and policy is entitled to the utmost respect by this court. Moreover, the Justices should never substitute their views on matters of judgment and policy for those of the Legislature. However, it always has been and still is our solemn constitutional and statutory obligation to make the ultimate decision on constitutional questions. This is precisely what the majority have done.”
